result.story: Another cocktail originating in Cuba in the early 20th century ‚Äì and another mystery. Who drank history‚Äôs first Daiquiri? Was it the locals who frequented a beach called Daiquiri near Santiago, or was it a bunch of Americans working in a nearby iron mine? In either case, it‚Äôs likely that the first Daiquiris were made with ice shaved off big blocks as was the practice a century ago. In the 1920s the Daiquiri found a new (and historically reliable) champion in Constantino Ribalaigua, the bartender and later owner of Havana‚Äôs El Floridita bar who improved the original Daiquiri recipe by adding crushed ice and maraschino liqueur.

result.story: The hype started some 80 years ago, and the White Russian has had its ups and downs, but it's never really gone out of style. This version was revitalized in the 90‚Äôs thanks to a certain bowling comedy character, and it is still just as invigorating as it is stylish. Old-school bartenders make White Russians with cream, or half cream/half milk.

result.story: Opening a shaker and pouring a drink is kind of similar to unboxing a new gadget ‚Äì the same excitement, the same anticipation. But try to take the time to really enjoy the drink, before you start thinking about your next one.
